1.learning_goal: Foundations of OOP: In this unit, students will build a foundational understanding of object-oriented programming by identifying and using core OOP concepts (class, object/instance, attribute, method, module), recognizing real-world and Python examples as objects with state and behavior, importing and working with built-in classes (like Random), defining simple custom classes (with and without constructors), creating multiple instances with independent state, writing and calling instance methods that use self and attributes, and composing small programs where objects from different classes interact.

chapters.title: Introduction to Object-Oriented Thinking
chapters.learning_goals: Students will learn to think about programs in terms of objects that bundle data and behavior, and understand how classes act as blueprints for creating many similar objects. They will connect these ideas to real-world examples and familiar Python types, using correct OOP vocabulary (object, class, instance, state, behavior).

lessons.title: Opening session and Q&A
lessons.learning_outcomes: Ask questions, clarify concepts, and engage with instructors and peers in real-time.

lessons.title: Welcome to OOP!
lessons.learning_outcomes: Understand the overall goals of the OOP unit; Recognize how object-oriented programming will be used in upcoming lessons

lessons.title: What Is Object-Oriented Programming?
lessons.learning_outcomes: Identify object-oriented programming as a programming paradigm; Recognize that object-oriented programming organizes programs around objects; Learn about the history of programming languages and OOP; Recognize that Python is also OOP oriented, and common Python types they have already used are objects

lessons.title: Objects = Data + Behavior
lessons.learning_outcomes: Identify an object as an entity that combines data attributes (state) and behavior (actions); Distinguish between the state and behavior of real-world objects using correct terminology

lessons.title: Classes and Instances
lessons.learning_outcomes: Identify a class as a blueprint that defines shared structure and behavior; Recognize that multiple instances can be created from the same class and relate this idea to real-world examples, as well as common python objects like lists; Recognize basic CaptialCase convention for Class names

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Object Hunt in Your Room
lessons.learning_outcomes: Identify everyday objects as data + behavior and describe them using correct OOP vocabulary (object, state, behavior, class, instance).

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Story World Objects
lessons.learning_outcomes: Translate a short story scene into objects, their state, and behavior, and distinguish between class “types” and specific instances in that scene.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Python Object Detective
lessons.learning_outcomes: Inspect built-in Python objects (like strings and lists) to recognize that they are instances of classes with both attributes and methods.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Class vs Instance Matching Game
lessons.learning_outcomes: Correctly match real-world class “blueprints” (e.g., Car, Book) with multiple possible instances and explain how they share structure but differ in state.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Mini Object Catalog
lessons.learning_outcomes: Create a written or commented “catalog” of at least five classes and their example instances, clearly separating state (attributes) from behavior (actions).

lessons.title: Closing session
lessons.learning_outcomes: Wrap up the day togeher with your peers and ask final questions

chapters.title: First Steps with Objects
chapters.learning_goals: In this chapter, students will learn the core ideas and vocabulary of object-oriented programming in Python, including classes, objects, attributes, methods, and modules. They will practice importing built-in modules, creating and using objects (like Random and custom classes), and clearly distinguishing between class definitions, instantiation, and the data produced by object methods.

lessons.title: Opening session and Q&A
lessons.learning_outcomes: Ask questions, clarify concepts, and engage with instructors and peers in real-time.

lessons.title: Challenge 1: Core terms of OOP
lessons.learning_outcomes: Student demonstrates understanding and can successfully complete the required skills for this challenge

lessons.title: Quick Detour: Built-In Modules
lessons.learning_outcomes: Recognize a module as a collection of related Python code; Use an import statement to access code from a built-in module; Recognize that importing a module allows access to classes and objects defined inside it

lessons.title: Objects in Action
lessons.learning_outcomes: Recognize that calling Random() with parenthesis creates an object (instance) from a class; Understand that the object's actions are called and use methods on a Random object to trigger behavior and produce data; Distinguish between the object itself, its methods, and the data produced by those methods; Recognize that class names in Python are typically written using CapitalCase by convention

lessons.title: Creating your First Class
lessons.learning_outcomes: Ability to define a minimal Python class using the class keyword without providing an __init__ method; Ability to create objects from a basic class, inspect its type, and assign attributes to those objects after instantiation; Ability to diffrentiate between class definition and instantiation, prefereably using comments in code

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: OOP Core Terms Flashcards
lessons.learning_outcomes: Use and explain core OOP terms (class, object, instance, attribute, method, module) accurately in the context of small code snippets.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Dice Roller with random Module
lessons.learning_outcomes: Import a built-in module, create an object from a class inside it, and call its methods to generate and print random dice rolls.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Random Story Prompt Generator
lessons.learning_outcomes: Use a Random object’s methods to produce randomized outputs while distinguishing clearly between the object, its methods, and the returned data.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: First Simple Class: Notebook
lessons.learning_outcomes: Define a minimal class in Python, create Notebook objects from it, assign attributes after instantiation, and inspect their type.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Class Definition vs Instantiation Notes
lessons.learning_outcomes: Write a short Python file with comments that clearly separate the class definition from instance creation and later attribute assignment.

lessons.title: Closing session
lessons.learning_outcomes: Wrap up the day togeher with your peers and ask final questions

chapters.title: Classes, Objects, and Methods
chapters.learning_goals: Learn how to define simple classes, create multiple objects that each maintain their own independent state, and distinguish between variable names and object attributes. Begin using instance methods (with self) and dot notation to trigger behavior on different objects.

lessons.title: Opening session and Q&A
lessons.learning_outcomes: Ask questions, clarify concepts, and engage with instructors and peers in real-time.

lessons.title: Creating Multiple Objects from One Class
lessons.learning_outcomes: Capability to explain that each object created from a class maintains its own independent set of attribute values; Ability to create a class from scratch, and then instantiate two or more objects from it and assign different attribute values, then observe those differences when printing; Ability to seperate between the variable name (the one that holds the instance) and the attributes inside an instance

lessons.title: Challenge 2: Creating Classes, Instances & Object State
lessons.learning_outcomes: Student demonstrates understanding and can successfully complete the required skills for this challenge

lessons.title: Methods
lessons.learning_outcomes: Ability to write a class definition with a method with self as its first parameter (without diving into what is self); Understand the self parameter in a shallow way (as a mandatory part of method definition), for now no need to understand the meaning of it or the value; Ability to create an object and call its instance method using dot notation to trigger the defined behavior

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Pet Profiles
lessons.learning_outcomes: Define a Pet class, create multiple Pet objects with different attribute values, and demonstrate that each object maintains its own independent state.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Library Books Tracker
lessons.learning_outcomes: Instantiate several Book objects from one class, assign distinct attributes, and print them to compare how instances differ while sharing the same blueprint.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Variable Name vs Attribute Name
lessons.learning_outcomes: Create objects with different variable names but similar attributes to clearly distinguish the variable that holds the instance from the attributes inside it.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Greeting Card Method
lessons.learning_outcomes: Write a class with a simple instance method using self and call that method on multiple objects to trigger behavior through dot notation.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Cafe Order Tickets - Part 1
lessons.learning_outcomes: Define an Order class, create multiple Order instances with different customer and item attributes, and print them to observe independent object state.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Cafe Order Tickets - Part 2
lessons.learning_outcomes: Add an instance method to the Order class that prints a formatted ticket using self, and show how calling it on different orders reflects each order’s state.

lessons.title: Closing session
lessons.learning_outcomes: Wrap up the day togeher with your peers and ask final questions

chapters.title: Building and Using Python Objects
chapters.learning_goals: Learn how to define classes, use `self`, and write constructors to create and manage object state, then combine multiple interacting objects in small, real-world-style Python programs.

lessons.title: Opening session and Q&A
lessons.learning_outcomes: Ask questions, clarify concepts, and engage with instructors and peers in real-time.

lessons.title: The self param, and Methods That Use Attributes
lessons.learning_outcomes: Understand the meaning of the self param; Ability to write an instance method that accesses attributes via self to produce output such as printing a stored name; Capability to reason about how changes to object attributes affect the behavior of instance methods that reference those attributes

lessons.title: Integrated Practice: Using and Creating Objects Together
lessons.learning_outcomes: Ability to compose a small Python program that defines and uses classes and objects, representing real life entities; Capability to trace how objects created from different classes interact through method calls and attribute access in a simple application

lessons.title: Constructors: Where Objects Begin
lessons.learning_outcomes: Understand the __init__ syntax, and the idea of a constructor; Recognize that __init__ runs automatically when an object is created using print; Write a class with an __init__ method that assigns default attribute values on self; Create an object and access attributes initialized in the constructor

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Name Tag Printer
lessons.learning_outcomes: Write a class with an instance method that uses self to read attributes and print a personalized “name tag,” then observe how changing attributes changes output.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Character Stats and Actions
lessons.learning_outcomes: Create a simple game character class where methods use self to reference and display attributes, demonstrating how attribute changes affect method behavior.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Student and Course Roster
lessons.learning_outcomes: Compose a small program with at least two classes (e.g., Student and Course) whose objects interact via method calls and attribute access.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: To-Do List App - Part 1
lessons.learning_outcomes: Define basic classes (e.g., Task and TaskList), create objects, and write methods that use self to access and print stored task information.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: To-Do List App - Part 2
lessons.learning_outcomes: Extend the To-Do list classes with methods that modify attributes via self (like marking tasks complete) and observe how behavior changes with state.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Constructor-Based Profile Setup
lessons.learning_outcomes: Write a class with an __init__ constructor that assigns default attribute values on self, then create and inspect objects to confirm initialization behavior.

lessons.title: Closing session
lessons.learning_outcomes: Wrap up the day togeher with your peers and ask final questions

chapters.title: Weekly Review
chapters.learning_goals: Review key concepts learned during the week and complete the weekly assessment.

lessons.title: Weekly Review Prep Session
lessons.learning_outcomes: We'll review key concepts and prepare for the assessment

lessons.title: Prep Lesson
lessons.learning_outcomes: Prep lesson for the weekly review

lessons.title: Weekly Review Assessment
lessons.learning_outcomes: Ask questions and get clarification

2.learning_goal: Object State & Inheritance: In this unit, students will learn to design and work with stateful objects by using constructors, validation, and encapsulation (getters/setters), then build on this to create and override behavior in class hierarchies using inheritance.

chapters.title: Mastering Object State and Constructors
chapters.learning_goals: In this chapter, students will learn how to read, compare, and predict object state, as well as design and use constructors with inputs and validation. They will practice keeping objects in safe, consistent states through real-world examples and applied coding challenges.

lessons.title: Opening session and Q&A
lessons.learning_outcomes: Ask questions, clarify concepts, and engage with instructors and peers in real-time.

lessons.title: Challenge 1: Object State in Action
lessons.learning_outcomes: Student demonstrates understanding and can successfully complete the required skills for this challenge

lessons.title: Reading Object State
lessons.learning_outcomes: Read and interpret the current state of an object by inspecting its attributes; Compare the state of multiple objects and explain why their values differ; Predict object state after a sequence of constructor and method calls; Identify which attributes changed and which remained the same during execution

lessons.title: Constructors with Inputs
lessons.learning_outcomes: Write an __init__ method that receives parameters and assigns them to attributes; Instantiate objects by passing arguments to the constructor; Recognize that required constructor parameters must be provided; Predict initial object state based on constructor arguments

lessons.title: Keeping Objects Valid
lessons.learning_outcomes: Add validation logic inside __init__; Apply safe fallback values when constructor inputs are invalid; Reason about how validation prevents bugs in later method behavior; Recognize validation as part of responsible object design, with real life examples

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Student profile tracker
lessons.learning_outcomes: Practice reading and comparing object state by inspecting attributes of multiple instances and explaining why their values differ.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Book order receipt
lessons.learning_outcomes: Predict and verify object state after a sequence of constructor and method calls that update order details.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Event ticket constructor
lessons.learning_outcomes: Use constructors with inputs to instantiate objects and accurately predict their initial state based on constructor arguments.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Fitness app user setup
lessons.learning_outcomes: Add validation logic inside __init__ to keep objects in a valid state and apply safe fallback values for invalid input.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Library membership validator
lessons.learning_outcomes: Combine constructor parameters and validation to ensure new objects always start in a safe, consistent state.

lessons.title: Closing session
lessons.learning_outcomes: Wrap up the day togeher with your peers and ask final questions

chapters.title: Encapsulation & Stateful Objects
chapters.learning_goals: Learn to design and work with stateful objects using constructors, instance variables, and methods, while tracing how object state changes over time. Apply encapsulation through getters and setters—with validation—to protect and manage internal state in practical scenarios like bank accounts, playlists, to-do lists, and thermostats.

lessons.title: Opening session and Q&A
lessons.learning_outcomes: Ask questions, clarify concepts, and engage with instructors and peers in real-time.

lessons.title: Challenge 2: Constructors & Object Validity
lessons.learning_outcomes: Student demonstrates understanding and can successfully complete the required skills for this challenge

lessons.title: Practice: Stateful Objects
lessons.learning_outcomes: Implement a small stateful class from scrath, that combines constructor parameters, instance variables, and methods; Trace object behavior across creation, method calls, state changes, and validation

lessons.title: Encapsulation: Owning Object State
lessons.learning_outcomes: Explain the principle of encapsulation, as one of the core OOP principles; Use internal attributes to store object state; Use getter methods to read object data instead of direct access

lessons.title: Encapsulation: Protecting Object State
lessons.learning_outcomes: Use setter methods to update object state; Apply simple validation rules inside setters to prevent invalid state; Understand the power of protecting object state with encapsulation

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Bank account state
lessons.learning_outcomes: Implement a small stateful class from scratch and trace its state across deposits, withdrawals, and balance checks.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Music playlist encapsulation
lessons.learning_outcomes: Use internal attributes and getter methods to read object data without directly exposing internal state.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: To-do list manager - Part 1
lessons.learning_outcomes: Implement a stateful class that owns its state, using methods to add and inspect tasks via getters.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: To-do list manager - Part 2
lessons.learning_outcomes: Add setter-style methods with validation to safely update and protect the internal state of the to-do list.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Thermostat controller
lessons.learning_outcomes: Apply encapsulation with getters and setters to enforce valid temperature ranges and prevent invalid state changes.

lessons.title: Closing session
lessons.learning_outcomes: Wrap up the day togeher with your peers and ask final questions

chapters.title: Encapsulation and Inheritance in Practice
chapters.learning_goals: Learn how to design classes that hide and protect internal state using getters and setters, and apply validation to control how data is accessed and modified. Build on this by creating inheritance hierarchies where subclasses reuse and extend behavior from parent classes in practical, real-world scenarios.

lessons.title: Opening session and Q&A
lessons.learning_outcomes: Ask questions, clarify concepts, and engage with instructors and peers in real-time.

lessons.title: Practice: Encapsulation in Action
lessons.learning_outcomes: Implement a small class from scratch using internal attributes, getters, and setters; Update and read object state safely through methods

lessons.title: Challenge: Encapsulation
lessons.learning_outcomes: Apply encapsulation by designing a class that hides internal state; Use getters and setters with validation to control how data is accessed and modified

lessons.title: Inheritance
lessons.learning_outcomes: Explain the principle of inheritance, as one of the core OOP principles; Create a subclass that inherits attributes and methods from a parent class; Use inherited behavior on subclass objects

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Recipe card encapsulation
lessons.learning_outcomes: Implement a class that hides its internal attributes and uses getters and setters to manage recipe details safely.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: User profile privacy
lessons.learning_outcomes: Apply encapsulation to protect sensitive profile fields and control how they can be read and updated.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Game character stats
lessons.learning_outcomes: Use getters and setters with validation to manage character health, experience, and level while preventing invalid values.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Vehicle inheritance basics
lessons.learning_outcomes: Create a subclass that inherits attributes and methods from a parent Vehicle class and use inherited behavior on subclass objects.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Notification system hierarchy - Part 1
lessons.learning_outcomes: Design a base Notification class with encapsulated state and methods for sending generic notifications.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Notification system hierarchy - Part 2
lessons.learning_outcomes: Create specialized subclasses that inherit from the base class and use encapsulated behavior through getters and setters.

lessons.title: Closing session
lessons.learning_outcomes: Wrap up the day togeher with your peers and ask final questions

chapters.title: Inheritance and Overriding in Action
chapters.learning_goals: Learn how to design and implement class hierarchies using inheritance, override methods to customize behavior, and predict which implementations run at runtime across diverse, related objects.

lessons.title: Opening session and Q&A
lessons.learning_outcomes: Ask questions, clarify concepts, and engage with instructors and peers in real-time.

lessons.title: Inheritance: Sometimes kids are not like their parents
lessons.learning_outcomes: Override a method in a subclass to change behavior; Predict which method implementation runs for a subclass object

lessons.title: Practice: Inheritance in Action
lessons.learning_outcomes: Implement a small class hierarchy with overridden behavior; Use different subclass objects in the same program

lessons.title: Challenge: Inheritance
lessons.learning_outcomes: Design a small set of related classes using inheritance and overriding

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Animal sounds override
lessons.learning_outcomes: Override methods in subclasses to change behavior and predict which implementation runs for each animal object.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Discount calculator inheritance
lessons.learning_outcomes: Use inheritance and method overriding so different customer types apply different discount rules in a shared system.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Transport tickets hierarchy - Part 1
lessons.learning_outcomes: Implement a small class hierarchy for tickets that shares common behavior through a base class.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Transport tickets hierarchy - Part 2
lessons.learning_outcomes: Override pricing or validation methods in subclasses to customize behavior for different ticket types.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Shape drawing tools
lessons.learning_outcomes: Use a set of related shape classes with inheritance and overriding to produce different drawing outputs from a common interface.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: RPG ability system
lessons.learning_outcomes: Design related classes using inheritance and overriding so different abilities share a base design but behave differently when used.

lessons.title: Closing session
lessons.learning_outcomes: Wrap up the day togeher with your peers and ask final questions

chapters.title: Weekly Review
chapters.learning_goals: Review key concepts learned during the week and complete the weekly assessment.

lessons.title: Weekly Review Prep Session
lessons.learning_outcomes: We'll review key concepts and prepare for the assessment

lessons.title: Prep Lesson
lessons.learning_outcomes: Prep lesson for the weekly review

lessons.title: Weekly Review Assessment
lessons.learning_outcomes: Ask questions and get clarification
